Q: Android Studio: The emulator is already running A:

For Linux, create an executable script that contains this (it depends on package psmisc, Artix Linux):

#!/bin/bash

# Kill x86 + x86_64 emulator instances
killall qemu-system-x86_64 -9
killall qemu-system-i386 -9

# Delete all lock files
for n in `find ~/.android/avd/ -name "*.lock"`; do rm -v $n;done

Q: How to scale down my slider so it has space around it A:

From what I can gather, I think you’re mainly trying to give the slider some space so it doesn’t stretch all the way across the page. You can simply limit the width of the slider and centre it. For example:

#slider {
    overflow: hidden;
    max-width: 900px;
    margin: 40px auto;  /* centres it and adds space around it */
    padding: 0 15px;    /* optional inner spacing */
}

Adjust the width, margin and padding to whatever fits your layout. In many cases, adding padding around the slider (or wrapping it in a container div) is all you need.

A few other points that might help

1. Semantics
Your slider uses a <figure> containing several images. <figure> is intended for one piece of media (optionally with a <figcaption>), not a collection.

2. Accessibility
Auto-playing sliders can be difficult for some users, and yours doesn’t currently offer any way to pause or navigate manually. If this slider is more than just decorative, think about adding controls and making sure they’re keyboard-accessible. Also consider:

  • using meaningful alt text (or alt="" for decorative images)

  • providing a visible focus outline

  • labelling the region, e.g.:

<div id="slider" role="region" aria-label="Featured image slider">
    …
</div>

3. CSS structure / naming
At the moment you’re styling everything via #slider. IDs work, but they’re very rigid. As your project grows, using a naming convention like BEM (e.g. .slider, .slider__track, .slider__slide) usually makes styles easier to scale, reuse and maintain. Classes are also more flexible than IDs in general.

Q: Is parsing JSON faster than parsing XML A:

The difference in performance will be so tiny, you wouldn't even notice it (and: you shouldn't think about performance problems until you have performance problems - there are a lot of more important points to care for - maintainable, readable and documented code...).

But, to answer your question: JSON will be faster to parse (because it's simple javascript object notation).

Q: How can I wait in a batch script? A:

Use:

@echo off
set wait=%1
echo waiting %wait% s
echo wscript.sleep %wait%000 > wait.vbs
wscript.exe wait.vbs
del wait.vbs

Q: Terminology for a value that has a particular type in Haskell A:

I guess that what I want is a general way to refer to a thing that has a given type. That it is bound to a variable isn't essential, so "mystack is of type State [Int] Int " isn't enough, because that requires the name mystack. That is how I asked the question, though.

Now I can say something like "In this function definition, the first term/expression/inhabitant of type State [Int] Int contains a function such that ..., while the second term/expression/inhabitant of that type contains a different function." Not sure that "contains" is appropriate, but I'd leave that for a different question. People sometimes talk about monads as containers, even though that doesn't always seem sensible, e.g. for Nothing. Good to know about "action". Sounds odd to me, but still.
